ygData.subject: Re: Mutation question
ygData.msgSnippet: The motivation for disabling as opposed to deleting was to keep the genetic history of any genome intact and accurate.  Since NEAT uses the history to tell

Subject: Re: Mutation question
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=0u9rYlrvsRpD5bavR_argyxssEq7DI6V9cLoMiY9YXeZcvOr58Sd

The motivation for disabling as opposed to deleting was to keep the
genetic history of any genome intact and accurate.  Since NEAT uses
the history to tell what the different species are, you will get more
accurate speciation (in terms of ancestral relatedness) by keeping
links around that are disabled, because they can be considered in
compatibility comparisons. 

A separate reason to keep them around is the theory that what was once
useful is likely to become useful again.  Many people believe this to
be the case for "introns," which are essentially the biological
version of disabled genes in NEAT: introns are biological genes in the
genome that are not expressed in the phenotype.  However, scientists
have pointed out that introns sometimes come back into play in the
future, and so may be a useful store of "old solutions."  NEAT has the
same capability be reenabling (as occasionally occurs) disabled genes.

The reason none of this comes to play in XOR is likely because XOR is
so simple.  There are so many ways to solve it compactly that it
doesn't really matter how you measure compatibility or whether you
have to rediscover the same thing again (since there are so few
options anyway).

However, they may come into play in more complex problems.

Still, that's not to say that anything is proven.  There has been muc
discussion on this board about the utility of deleting genes, and in
some cases it does appear to offer a measurable benefit.  Therefore,
this question can be considered to be ultimately empirical, and I
*think* it is still not settled (i.e. the particular question of
disabling vs. deleting when splitting a link).  It is actually quite
possible neither way offers much advantage.  The larger question of
whether deletion of some sort in general is desirable is probably more
signifiant.

ken 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Matt Simmerson" <m.simmerson@b...> wrote:
> Hi
> 
> When an add node mutation occurs, currently (AFAIK) it is best
> paractice to just disable the mutated link.  Has anyone tried removing
> it from the genome all together.  Is this a sensible thing to do, I
> guess the answer is suck it and see.
> 
> I did test it with the XOR experiment and it worked fine.  Just
> wondered if there were any advantages/disadvantages with this approach.
> 
> Any comments would be appreciated.
> 
> Cheers
> 
> Matt
